material.mattext:
Quiz 7 - Wheeled robot kinematics

This quiz covers Chapter 6 of the notes.

 Instructions

  • This quiz consists of 10 questions, covering content from the previous week.
  • You are allowed to submit the quiz an unlimited number of times with no time limit, and on each submission you can review each incorrect question attempt after the fact.
  • When reattempting the quiz, only the previously incorrect question(s) from the last attempted quiz will be available to attempt. The correct question(s) from the last attempted quiz will automatically be added to your score.
The instantaneous centre of rotation for a differentially-steered robot is, in general, constrained to lie on the line defined by
Under what condition will the instantaneous centre of rotation be located at the wheel-to-wheel centre of the differentially-steered robot?
When the robot experiences a pure rotational velocity without a translational velocity.
When the robot experiences a pure translational velocity without a rotational velocity.
When the robot experiences both a translational velocity and a rotational velocity.
The instantaneous centre of rotation will never be at the centre of mass of the robot.

Given left and right wheel translational velocities of $$ \{v_L,v_R\}=\{1,2\}, $$ and a wheel-to-wheel distance of \(d=0.1\) metres, determine the body-frame translational velocity in the x-axis, \(v\), and the rotational velocity, \(\dot{\psi}\).
Given left and right wheel translational velocities of $$ \{v_L,v_R\}=\{1,2\}, $$ and a wheel-to-wheel distance of \(d=0.1\) metres, determine the pose-rate vector when \(\psi = \frac{\pi}{4}\).

Given left and right wheel translational velocities of $$ \{v_L,v_R\}=\{1,2\}, $$ and a wheel-to-wheel distance of \(d=0.1\) metres, determine the location of the instantaneous centre of rotation with respect to the body frame.

Given left and right wheel translational velocities of $$ \{v_L,v_R\}=\{1,2\}, $$ and a wheel-to-wheel distance of \(d=0.1\) metres, determine the world-frame location of the instantaneous centre of rotation when \(\psi = \frac{\pi}{4}\) and \( ^W{\bf t}_B=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1  \end{bmatrix}^T\).

Given left and right wheel translational velocities of $$ \{v_L,v_R\}_k=\{1,2\} $$ at time instance \(k\), and a wheel-to-wheel distance of \(d=0.1\) metres, use odometry to estimate the world-frame pose at time instance \(k+1\) when $$ {^W{\bf \xi}_B}_k=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & \frac{\pi}{4} \end{bmatrix}^T,$$ and \(\Delta t=0.1\) seconds.

Determine the relationship between the frame \(\{A\}\) and world-frame translational velocities when the frame \(\{A\}\) origin is placed at 

$$^B{\bf p} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.15 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, $$

and the frame \(\{B\}\) origin is located at the robot's wheel-to-wheel centre. You can assume that frame \(\{A\}\) and frame \(\{B\}\) have equivalent orientations.

Given a desired pose-rate vector of

$$ ^W{\dot{\bf \xi}_A} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T, $$

determine the instantaneous robot velocities required when the frame \(\{A\}\) origin is placed at 

$$^B{\bf p} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.15 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, $$

and the frame \(\{B\}\) origin is located at the robot's wheel-to-wheel centre, with an orientation of \(\psi=\frac{\pi}{4} \) with respect to \(\{W\}\).

Given a desired pose-rate vector of

$$ ^W{\dot{\bf \xi}_A} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T, $$

determine the instantaneous wheel velocities required when the frame \(\{A\}\) origin is placed at 

$$^B{\bf p} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.15 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, $$

and the frame \(\{B\}\) origin is located at the robot's wheel-to-wheel centre, with \(^W\psi=\frac{\pi}{4} \) and wheel-to-wheel distance \(d=0.1\) metres.
